inlineContent.text: Learn advanced user management operations with the Parse-Swift SDK.

This tutorial covers user login, updating user properties, fetching user data with included pointer fields, email verification, password reset, anonymous login, and session management. Building on the
tutorial, you’ll master the complete user lifecycle.
This tutorial assumes you have already completed
and
tutorials, and have initialized the Parse SDK. If you haven’t done so, please refer to those tutorials first.
Before working with users, you need to define a custom User struct that conforms to the
protocol.
The User model includes required Parse fields plus any custom properties specific to your application.
Include the required
properties (
) and required
properties (
). Add a custom property like
Create a
struct that conforms to
The merge method is optional but recommended for faster decoding after updates. It specifies how to merge server data with local changes for custom properties.
Implement a custom
method for optimal performance.
This allows you to create User instances with specific values for signup.
Add custom initializers in an extension to preserve the memberwise initializer.
This ParseObject will be used to demonstrate relationships between User and other objects. The GameScore model includes a
property and its own merge method.
Define a
model for use with pointer fields.
Now that GameScore is defined, you can add it as a property to the User model. The merge method is also updated to handle the gameScore field.
Add the
pointer field to your User model.
Authenticate users with their username and password using the
method.
Parse-Swift provides async/await methods for logging in users, which automatically stores the current user locally.
The login method authenticates the user with Parse Server and returns the logged-in user object.
Login a user with their username and password using async/await.
After a successful login, Parse automatically stores the user locally. You can access it using
Verify the current user is stored locally after login.
Modify user properties using the
method or
property.
These approaches ensure only changed fields are sent to the server, improving performance and reducing network traffic.
The
method allows you to chain updates to multiple fields. Only the modified fields will be sent to Parse Server when you call
Update user properties using the
method.
The
property returns a version of the user that tracks which fields have been modified, allowing direct property assignment.
Alternatively, use
to update properties directly.
When fetching users, pointer fields like
are not automatically included. Use
to fetch related objects in a single request.
This is more efficient than fetching pointer objects separately.
Use
parameter to specify which pointer fields should be fully populated. This example includes the
field.
Fetch a user with specific pointer fields included.
The wildcard
includes all pointer fields in the fetch operation, ensuring you get the complete user data.
Fetch a user with all pointer fields included using

tasks.title: Fetch user data with included pointer fields

inlineContent.text: Remove the current user session and clear local storage.
Logging out ensures the user’s session token is invalidated and they must login again to perform authenticated operations.
The
method clears the current user from local storage and invalidates the session on Parse Server.
Logout the current user using async/await.
Create new user accounts with additional custom properties beyond the standard username, password, and email.
You can add any custom fields to your User model and set them before signing up.
Set custom properties on the user instance before calling
. The user will be created on Parse Server with all the specified fields.
Create and signup a user with custom fields.
Parse provides built-in email verification and password reset functionality.
These features help secure user accounts and provide a smooth user experience for account recovery.
Parse Server will send a verification email to the specified address. The user must click the link in the email to verify their account.
Request an email verification for a user.
Parse Server will send a password reset email to the specified address. The user can click the link to reset their password.
Request a password reset email.
Anonymous login allows users to interact with your app without creating an account.
You can later convert anonymous users to regular users, preserving their data. Session tokens authenticate user requests to Parse Server.
Anonymous login creates a temporary user account that can be used immediately without signup. This is useful for onboarding flows.
Login anonymously without credentials.
The session token is a unique identifier used to authenticate user requests. It’s automatically managed by Parse but can be accessed if needed.
Access the session token for the current user.
Set a username and password on the anonymous user and call
to convert them. All data associated with the anonymous user is preserved.
Convert an anonymous user to a regular user.

abstract.text: A pure Swift library that gives you access to the powerful Parse Server backend from Swift applications built for iOS, macOS, watchOS, tvOS, visionOS, Android, Linux, and Windows.
